chapter.title: Introductory Examples
chapter.para: This section provides a set of examples that show some of the fundamental aspects of Tapestry. It begins with a discussion on Tapestry binding, which is the process by which you as a developer link your objects to the components in the HTML page. Moving on, we create a simple multiple page application using the &Page; component, and then show how to respond to user actions (typically Submit buttons) via the &Action; component.
More advanced examples can be found from onwards.

section.title: Introduction to Tapestry Binding
section.para: Most components have more than a single property. For example, the &Form; component typically requires that both listener and delegate properties be set to something meaningful.

There are multiple ways to provide values for the component properties:
Property Binding
Binds a component value to something, using an &OGNL; (Object Graph Navigation Language) expression. This is the most flexible binding type within Tapestry. These bindings in the most part look like JavaBean property names strung together with dots. e.g: visit.name, would work against against the following object graph: this.getVisit().getName(). Virtually anything can be references by an &OGNL; expression, including methods, JavaBean properties and static fields (Boolean.TRUE).
All OGNL expressions are evaluated in the context of a current object, and a chain simply uses the result of the previous link in the chain as the current object for the next one. You can extend a chain as long as you like. (from &OGNL; web site) In Tapestry, the current object that you start with is the object for the page in question. For the 'hello world' application covered previously, this is the OGNL expressions must begin their evaluation somewhere. In Tapestry, this is the tutorial.hello.Home obect. Lets run through a few quick examples:
Use sometext to access public String getSomeText() from the example Use sometext.length() to access the length() method of the String object returned by the getSomeText() methodd. Use true to refer to the constant which equals 'true' or Boolean.TRUE Use user.listAllCustomers() to get the Collection from the method currentPageObject.getUser().listAllCustomers() which is a member of the current page object Use @com.someplace.MyClass@interestingMethod("hello world") to return the value from the static method com.someplace.MyClass.interestingMethod(String arg) Use @Boolean@TRUE to refer to Boolean.TRUE
This section provides only a brief introdcution to the use of OGNL. For a full explanation, see the &OGNL; website.
Static Binding
A completely static piece of text, hardcoded into the component specification.
Field Binding
Refers to a static member variable on some class, e.g: Boolean.TRUE or com.mycompany.myclass.MyObject.SOMEVAR. Static bindings must use full qualified object names, except if the property being referenced is part of java.lang
String Binding
Used for localization, the value of this binding should refer to some localized asset.
